docs.lead_paragraph: After months of intense lobbying over the issue, Senate Republicans agreed today to schedule debate and a vote in the spring on a bipartisan bill that would guarantee health insurance coverage for people who leave employer-sponsored plans. Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, the Kansas Republican who is a co-sponsor of the bill, said tonight that Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, would bring the bill to the Senate floor between April 15 and May 3.

headline.main: Critics to Allow Vote on Health Insurance Bill

docs.snippet: After months of intense lobbying over the issue, Senate Republicans agreed today to schedule debate and a vote in the spring on a bipartisan bill that would guarantee health insurance coverage for people who leave employer-sponsored plans.        ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's governors voted unanimously at their conference yesterday for reforms of welfare and Medicaid that are harsher toward the poor in key respects than anything Congress has passed or that the Republicans privately negotiated with President Clinton in their ill-fated budget talks. This unfortunate outcome is the price for achieving the governors' primary goal of protecting state treasuries. What they did not achieve is a proposal that would guarantee essential security for the impoverished. A civilized, wealthy society should do no less. On Medicaid, the governors said their plan would split the difference between turning the health insurance program over to the states to run, as the G.O.P. wants, and preserving the existing entitlement that poor families have to medical coverage. But the entitlement has shriveled. The governors' plan would guarantee undefined medical benefits to a diminished group of recipients.

docs.lead_paragraph: As more than 30,000 striking maintenance workers returned to work, union leaders tried to cast their agreement to end the walkout as a victory for labor even though the union was forced to accept a lower starting salary for new workers. Eager to be seen as getting his leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. off to a successful start, John J. Sweeney, the Federation's new president, came to New York City to assert that the union won the 30-day-strike because the contract improves wages and a variety of benefits for current employees.

headline.main: Union Leaders Claim Victory in Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: Shortly after AIDS was first recognized in 1981, activists demanded: give us new therapies. Now the latest worry of activists and many others concerned about the costs of health care is: who can afford them? A five-day meeting on H.I.V. and related viruses here last week made it clear that the treatment of AIDS is entering a new phase, much more complex, perhaps more effective and certainly more costly.

headline.main: The Doctor's World;New AIDS Therapies Arise, But Who Can Afford the Bill?

byline.original: By By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers who receive employer-provided health insurance for an adult companion to whom they are not married must pay income taxes on the benefit unless they provide more than half of the companion's support, the Internal Revenue Service said. The I.R.S. policy was detailed in a private-letter ruling issued Jan. 19 to an unnamed international law firm. Such rulings apply only to those the letter addresses, but are followed closely by tax experts as a guide to the agency's thinking.

headline.main: I.R.S Details a Policy in Ruling On Companions' Health Benefit

docs.lead_paragraph: A leading organization of statisticians accused the health insurance industry's chief lobbying group today of greatly exaggerating the cost of legislation designed to enable people who lose group coverage to buy individual policies. The bill, sponsored by Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has been kept off the Senate floor since last summer by individual senators, who, by Senate custom, have not been publicly identified. But Mrs. Kassebaum, chairwoman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, said on Thursday she hoped that an agreement could be reached this week to take up the bill by May 3.

headline.main: Actuaries Fault Health Insurers' Stand on Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: New Government data show that Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund lost money last year for the first time since 1972, suggesting that the financial condition of the Medicare program is worse than assumed by either Congress or the Clinton Administration. In a report to Congress in April, the Administration estimated that the amount of money in the trust fund would increase by $4.7 billion in the 1995 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30. In fact, officials said in interviews, the balance in the trust fund fell by $35.7 million, to $129.5 billion.

headline.main: SHORTFALL POSTED BY MEDICARE FUND TWO YEARS EARLY

docs.lead_paragraph: Because Reggie Miller and his teammates knocked them out of the playoffs last season, the Knicks are prepared to use the Indiana Pacers as their most accurate measuring stick midway through the season. They are not playing down their victory over Orlando on Thursday or their two losses to Chicago as much as they are taking a hard look at where they have gone since Patrick Ewing's finger roll bounced off the rim in Game 7 last May.

docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when the Federal Government is squeezing many social programs, the veterans medical center here, on a serene 400-acre campus on Chesapeake Bay, has opened a cozy new refuge for people like Stanford Avant. After his discharge from the Marine Corps, with which he had served in Vietnam, Mr. Avant spent 25 tortured years "drinking and drugging," as he puts it, on the streets of Wilmington, Del. Now he is 46, and he has been at Perry Point since a sanctuary for homeless veterans opened here in September.

headline.main: Needs of Poor Veterans Draw New V.A. Focus
